title: Canadian-led patrol finds alleged shark finning, dolphin harvesting in North Pacific
description: A Canadian-led patrol of the North Pacific earlier this year uncovered dozens of alleged fisheries violations, including illegal shark finning and killing of dolphi…
content:
Get the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.

“This year’s operation was unique in that it was the first time Canada delivered direct air support to our own inspection vessel,” she said. “This means that our daily air missions provided vessel-sighting information directly to ship-based fishery officers who could then incorporate the aircraft’s findings into their patrol planning.”

Wheeler said there has been a reduction in “pirate” vessels, which are not registered to fish in the region, and there are signs the patrols are having an impact.

“We’ve been out there since the (1990s) but it’s actually in the last few years that the rule book has really changed and a lot of new requirements have come in. Some of these captains are just unaware or choose to ignore (the rules), and that’s where we’re seeing our presence actually starting to influence the behaviour.”

There are more than 1,100 vessels registered to fish in the jurisdiction of the North Pacific Fisheries Commission. All of the vessels inspected as part of this year’s annual patrol were permitted to fish in the region, Wheeler noted.

summary: A Canadian-led maritime patrol has found alleged shark finning, dolphin harvesting in the North Pacific. The operation was unique as it was the first time Canada provided direct air support to its own inspection vessel. There has been a decrease in "pirate" vessels, which are not registered to fish in the region, and signs of positive effects from the patrols.
shortSummary: A Canadian-led patrol found evidence of shark finning and dolphin harvesting in the North Pacific, reducing piracy, and may even have altered the course of events.
argos_summary: Canada has implemented a new operation this year, providing direct air support to its inspection vessel for the first time, enhancing the effectiveness of patrols against illegal fishing. The presence of 'pirate' vessels has decreased, indicating that the patrols are positively influencing fishing practices in the region. With over 1,100 registered vessels in the North Pacific Fisheries Commission's jurisdiction, all inspected vessels were found to be compliant with fishing regulations.
